paragraphs.content: A data type specifies the type of data that is being stored in a variable. In Java, as it is a strongly typed language, all variables must have a specified data type.
Integer data types store numeric whole numbers (without a decimal).

Byte: A byte is used for a really smaller integer between -128 and 127. Many programmers use this when they are sure the variable stored as a byte will not exceed the maximum byte values. This is generally used to save memory, therefore increasing efficiency.
Short: A short can store integers larger than a byte but smaller than an int. It can store integers between -32768 and 32767.

Int: An int is the most commonly used data type for storing integers. It can store integers between -2147483648 and 2147483647 (Pretty large!). Most Java programmers use this when storing any integer type variable.

Long: A long can store extremely large integers (between -9223372036854775808 and 9223372036854775807). This is only used in the rare occasion that an int is too small to store an integer. The value should end with an 'L' when stored as a long.
Floating point data types store numbers with a decimal.
Float: A float is used store store decimal numbers between 3.4e-038 and 3.4e+038 (six to seven digits after the point). The value should end with an 'f' when stored as a float.
Double: A double is used to store floating point numbers between 1.7e-308 and 1.7e+308 (15 digits after the point). The value should end with a 'd' when stored as a double.
Boolean: A boolean stores either true or false. They are primarily used in while loops (covered later).

paragraphs.content: Char: A char stores single characters only. The character being stored as a char must be surrounded with single quotation marks.
String: A String essentially combines and stores a list of characters. A String must be surrounded by double quotation marks to indicate its a String and not a char.
